isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - ELECTRONIC ENGINE CONTROLS - DETROIT DIESEL SERIES 60 - 1992 - 1993 - SYSTEM COMPONENTS AND OPERATION - IDLE SHUTDOWN

svcprocinfo.para: The customer selectable idle shutdown feature shuts down the engine (does not shut down power to the cab) after a customer selected (programmed) length of time between 3 and 100 minutes.
The timer (an ECM function) begins counting down if:

item.para: The parking brake is set, which closes Idle Timer Switch (268).
The engine is at normal operating temperature.
The engine speed is at idle rpm.
And the ECM does not see any clutch or brake pedal operation.

svcprocinfo.para: If these conditions are present, the ECM counts down the "customer selected length of time" until 90 seconds before the scheduled engine shutdown is to occur. At this time (90 seconds before shutdown), the yellow Check Engine Light (CEL) begins to flash rapidly. During this 90 second time frame, depressing the clutch or applying the throttle will CANCEL the shutdown.
The shutdown may also be programmed to operate on the PTO system.

note.para: The engine is shut down, BUT POWER TO THE CAB IS NOT TURNED OFF.

svcprocinfo.para: The only system component dedicated to the Idle Shutdown feature is the Idle Timer Switch. The other inputs (discussed later in this section) to the ECM are from the Throttle Position Sensor (267), Service Brake Switch (277), Clutch Switch (225) and engine speed and temperature information from DDEC sensors.

svcsubproc.title: Idle Timer Switch (269)
svcsubproc.para: The Idle Timer Switch (269) is a 2-pole switch that is closed when the park brake is applied. One switch pole is connected (97AV) to the ECM through connector (273), location H2. This location has 5V present. The other side of the switch is ground through circuit 97-GE. Closing the switch causes the voltage state at ECM location H2 to change from 5V to ground, indicating to the ECM that the park brake is set.
